Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Refreezing in the firn of the Greenland ice sheet: Spatiotemporal variability and implications for ice sheet mass balance
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Arctic is warming and the Greenland ice sheet is melting. In total, the ice sheet stores enough water to raise sea level by approximately 6 meters. However, how surface meltwater generated in the summer makes its way from its location on the ice sheet to the ocean is not well understood. Two competing but not mutually exclusive theories are 1) the meltwater percolates into the ice sheet pores and is stored for a relatively long time. 2) The initial infiltrating meltwater refreezes at shallow depth in the firm, forming a hard pan that prohibits further infiltration. In this latter case, the meltwater quickly moves downslope along the surface of the ice sheet until it drains into the ocean. Rennermalm will test these hypotheses through a combination of field work, remote sensing from satellites, and modeling. Moreover, Rennermalm believes that during the most recent warming, the shallow refreezing mechanism has been playing a lesser role in the delivery of meltwater to the ocean than in previous times. To explore this hypothesis Rennermalm will compare the physical characteristics of modern cores with those extracted from earlier expeditions.

The project will involve graduate and undergraduate student training. The PI?s will collaborate with the Rutgers Film Bureau to ensure effective communication with the public. The PI?s expect that the Rutgers Film Bureau director will seek to showcase the documentary at film festivals and other venues. In year one, two Rutgers Film Bureau members (the director and one student) will travel to Greenland to capture the day-to-day choices of scientific research in an extreme environment and produce a short multimedia narrative.

Sea level is expected to rise in the decades to come, partially due to the melting of the Greenland ice sheet. However, we do not fully understand how meltwater generated on the surface of the ice sheet makes its way to the ocean. One line of thinking is that surface meltwater makes its way into the porous ice sheet where it is stored, either refrozen or in a liquid state, for relatively long times. Alternatively, as proposed by these investigators, the first seasonal meltwater that makes its way into the shallow ice, refreezes and blocks further infiltration, resulting in water that quickly moves down the surface ice sheet until it enters the ocean. Knowing the fate of meltwater is imperative if we are to understand how fast sea level will rise in the future. These investigators will integrate field work, computer modeling, and analyze data from satellites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Melting of the Greenland ice sheet is one of the main drivers of the current global sea-level rise. About half of Greenland?s meltwater originates from low ice sheet elevation where it runs off in channels on and under the ice sheet. At higher elevations in the so-called percolation zone, meltwater may run off or infiltrate into the porous subsurface multiyear snow and ultimately refreeze at depth. This multiyear snow extends several 10s of meters below the surface and could theoretically accommodate vast amounts of meltwater. Following the extreme melt year of 2012, scientists discovered unusually thick, near-surface ice layers in the old multiyear snow. These ice layers may have prevented meltwater from infiltrating deeper into older snow layers and instead, this meltwater may have run off immediately.

 

In this project, 24 new shallow ice cores were collected between 2017-2019 in Southwest Greenland's percolation zone. By comparing these new ice cores with previously collected cores, we found that the capacity of multiyear snow to accommodate infiltrating meltwater decreased since 1989 and today. However, we also discovered that the ability of multiyear snow to accommodate meltwater infiltration increased between 2013 and 2019 in most of the percolation zone. We found an exception in the lowest elevation regions of the percolation zone. At these lowest elevations, thick ice layers remain near the surface year after year and suppress the development of porous multiyear snow despite decreases at higher elevations. In conclusion, for most of the percolation zone, we found that temporary buildup in porous multiyear snow is possible despite the long-term increase in Greenland ice sheet melting that started in the early 1990s and is projected to intensify in the coming decades

 

 

Besides the scientific findings, the project resulted in several other benefits for society. The 24 new shallow ice cores will be archived at a publicly available data repository and add to a sparse dataset of similar shallow ice cores. These data will be useful for generations to come as the Greenland ice sheet continues to be affected by global climate change. The fieldwork code of conduct, protocols, and procedures implemented in this project sets a new standard for promoting justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion in glaciological fieldwork. This project provided training and professional development for two undergraduate students, three graduate students, two postdoctoral researchers, and two early-career scientists. Finally, Utuqaq, A 27-minute film about the 2018 fieldwork by filmmaker Iva Radivojević is freely available online. This film provides a poetic portrait of scientists surveying the impacts of climate change on the Greenland ice sheet.
